awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Secondary Amine Selective Petasis (SASP) Bioconjugation
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Monika Raj from Auburn University to develop a chemical method that can selectively label a specific site on a biomolecule in the presence of sea of other similar sites.  In this case, the specifically labeled site is known to "turn on" or "turn off" very important functions inside the cell which are responsible for cell growth, as well as the transfer of information from one cell to another.  The proposal aims to use the new chemical labeling method to better understand the biological significance of the reactive sites, that is how they control cellular function.  Dr. Raj develops methods based on innovative applications of classical chemical reactions for visualizing biomolecules and tagging them with dye.  This project also supports continued efforts toward increasing diversity in science fields by allowing graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented minorities to gain training in both organic chemistry and biochemistry. Outreach activities engage high school students (especially women and underrepresented minorities) and expose them to basic concepts of science through fun experimentation, ultimately encouraging them to pursue studies and academic careers in STEM fields.

Chemical strategies that can target a particular functional group at a single site in the presence of reactive amino acid side chains on protein surfaces are limited. Even more rare are organic reactions that can proceed under conditions mild enough to label biomolecules. To address these challenges, this research project develops a new multicomponent bioconjugation method based on the classical organic Petasis reaction for selective labeling of proteins containing secondary amines. This method is employed for labeling mono-methyl lysine containing posttranslational modifications (PTMs) on proteins with various cargoes. The dysregulation of these mono methyl lysine PTMs has been linked to a variety of different biological malfunctions, yet the chemical methods for selective detection of mono methyl lysine PTMs are still lacking. This research provides a highly selective chemical tool that can effectively detect mono methyl lysine PTMs which, are present not only on histone proteins but also on other proteins and dictate various protein-protein interactions and functions. Thus, the proposed research has a great potential to further our understanding of how these PTMs regulate various cellular signaling processes and how the PTMs themselves are regulated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Post-translational modifications (PTMs) are small yet crucial changes made to proteins after they are built, enabling them to function properly and interact correctly within our cells. Understanding these modifications helps scientists figure out how proteins work correctly and what might go wrong in diseases. This knowledge is essential for developing new treatments for illnesses where these processes are disrupted. One type of PTM involves adding a small tag called a methyl group to a part of the protein called lysine. Adding these mono-methyl PTMs on the lysine side chain of a protein can turn proteins on or off or change their activity. These changes can send proteins to different parts of the cell. PTMs can also help proteins stick to other proteins or let go, much like how magnets can attract or repel each other. Due to their multiple key roles, these mono-methyl PTMs on lysine ensure that our cellular machinery operates smoothly. Therefore, developing methods to identify these monomethyl small tags is crucial for understanding their biological functions and discovering new early warning signs for various diseases. However, identifying these tiny tags on proteins is challenging due to their natural scarcity and the minimal change in size and charge of monomethyl lysine compared to natural lysine on proteins. Additionally, proteins are rich in several reactive amino acids, making it highly challenging to selectively tag this monomethyl lysine tag in their presence. The scientific goal of this project had two main objectives. The first was to develop chemical methods that allow for selective labeling of proteins at monomethyl lysine among many other reactive functional groups. The second was to use these new reactions for the selective identification of the number and sites of these monomethyl lysine PTMs to further understand their fundamental roles in various biological processes. The educational goal was to establish a summer workshop called, Protein Science Day, targeted at middle and high school students, particularly those from underrepresented groups in science. This workshop aimed to engage students in biochemistry activities related to proteins and provide the necessary social support to encourage them to pursue STEM majors in college. During the course of this NSF-supported project, significant progress was made, including the development of three methods for the selective labeling of monomethyl lysine PTM tags in the presence of other reactive amino acids on proteins:

  1. Secondary Amine Selective Petasis Reaction: A three-component reaction with aldehyde, boronic acid, and secondary amine.
  2. Selective Triazenation Reaction of Secondary Amines utilizing phenyl diazonium ions.
  3. Coarctate Reaction: Involves the simultaneous formation and breakage of two bonds at one atom forming heterocyclic ring at the site of monomethyl lysine.

These were the first methods ever reported for the selective tagging of secondary amines on proteins. Next, these selective bioconjugation reactions were used for tagging the monomethyl lysine tag in the proteome, and new sites of monomethyl lysine tags were identified. These selective reactions were also applied to other applications, including identifying the sites of monomethyl lysine tags by single molecule protein sequencing and making a library of therapeutic cyclic peptides in one pot.

The coarctate reaction was applied to 2-ethynylanline, resulting in the formation of 2-amine-2H-indazoles with inherent fluorescence. This fluorescence was significantly amplified and redshifted into the near-infrared (NIR) region. The coarctate reaction has been used to develop a mild photo-triggered approach for releasing 2-amine from 2-amine-2H-indazole, useful for live cell imaging and selective drug release from conjugates under biocompatible conditions.

Importantly, the project provided valuable training for undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs, helping them improve their technical and research skills and their professional development. New workshops have been established to engage middle and high school students, especially those from groups underrepresented in science, in hands-on biochemistry activities to inspire interest in STEM fields and provide the social support necessary for these students to pursue STEM majors in college.

Overall, this project has significantly contributed to the field of chemical biology by developing new bioconjugation techniques and applying them to understand fundamental biological processes. The innovative approaches to selective biomolecule labeling and drug delivery have the potential to impact a wide range of scientific and medical applications. Additionally, the project's outreach efforts are helping to build a more diverse and inclusive future generation of scientists

 


Last Modified: 07/02/2024
Modified by: Monika Raj
